Metro Exodus takes the claustrophobic tension of the earlier games and expands it into a sprawling, semi-open world — without losing its soul. You play as Artyom, leaving the tunnels of post-apocalyptic Moscow to search for a new life on the surface.

The game masterfully balances quiet exploration with brutal combat and powerful storytelling. Each region — from frozen forests to sun-scorched deserts — feels alive, dangerous, and hauntingly beautiful. The world tells its story through every ruin, radio transmission, and fleeting human moment.

Visually stunning and emotionally gripping, Metro Exodus is both a survival shooter and a deeply human journey about hope in a dying world.

Metro Exodus, developed by 4A Games and published by Deep Silver, represents a major turning point in the Metro series, taking its tense, claustrophobic survival horror roots and expanding them into a vast, open-world journey across a devastated post-apocalyptic Russia. It is both a continuation and a reinvention, following the story of Artyom, the silent protagonist from the previous games, as he leaves behind the dark tunnels of the Moscow Metro in search of a new life on the surface. What unfolds is a remarkable odyssey across a shattered landscape, carried by a haunting mix of human desperation, fragile hope, and the quiet beauty that still lingers in a ruined world. It is a game that manages to be grim and breathtaking at the same time—an experience that balances moments of intense combat and survival with periods of reflection, exploration, and storytelling rarely seen in first-person shooters.

The decision to move beyond the underground tunnels of the earlier games was a bold one, but it pays off magnificently. Metro Exodus takes players on a journey that spans an entire year, moving through multiple regions and biomes, from the frozen remnants of Moscow’s outskirts to the burning sands of the Caspian desert and the overgrown valleys of the Taiga. Each location is semi-open in design, allowing freedom of exploration while maintaining the series’ focus on atmosphere and tension. This hybrid approach works remarkably well—the game never loses the tightly scripted intensity that defined its predecessors, yet it introduces a sense of scale and unpredictability that keeps the experience fresh. Whether scavenging for filters in the wasteland, fighting off mutated creatures in abandoned ruins, or navigating the Aurora train that serves as your mobile home, every area feels alive, dangerous, and meaningful.

Survival remains at the core of the experience. Artyom is not a super-soldier; he is a fragile human in a hostile world. Resources are scarce, weapons require maintenance, and every bullet feels precious. The game’s crafting system deepens this tension by allowing players to assemble ammunition, filters, and weapon modifications at workbenches or in the field. This mechanic encourages cautious exploration and creates a tangible sense of progression as your tools evolve alongside your journey. The combat itself is methodical and weighty—guns feel heavy, enemies are deadly, and stealth remains a vital option for those who prefer patience over confrontation. The AI can be inconsistent at times, with some encounters feeling brilliantly unpredictable and others oddly mechanical, but when the systems align, the combat offers an immersive mix of tension and satisfaction that few shooters achieve.

The shift to open areas also allows the game to breathe in ways the earlier entries never could. Between firefights and scavenging runs, Metro Exodus offers moments of quiet introspection—sitting by a campfire with your companions, listening to a conversation between crew members, or simply watching the sunset through a cracked visor. These scenes lend emotional weight to the journey, grounding it in the humanity of its characters. Artyom’s companions aboard the Aurora—his wife Anna, the pragmatic Colonel Miller, and a host of fellow soldiers and survivors—form the emotional backbone of the story. Their interactions feel genuine, with each having their own hopes, fears, and motivations. The game takes time to explore these relationships, allowing you to form attachments that make later events hit harder. The writing is understated but effective, often conveyed through natural dialogue rather than exposition, and it contributes to the sense that these people are truly fighting for something more than just survival.

From a technical standpoint, Metro Exodus is a visual powerhouse. 4A Games has always been known for pushing hardware boundaries, and here they outdo themselves. The game’s environments are richly detailed and often stunning—snowy ruins glisten with eerie beauty, sun-drenched deserts shimmer with heat, and night sequences envelop you in darkness punctuated by flickering lights and glowing radiation. The lighting system, particularly in the Enhanced Edition with full ray tracing, creates scenes that border on photorealism, enhancing immersion to a level that few games match. Weather patterns, dynamic day-night cycles, and environmental storytelling all contribute to the sense of a living world that continues to decay and adapt long after humanity’s fall. The sound design is equally masterful, with distant roars, creaking metal, and muffled footsteps combining to create constant unease. Even the simple act of breathing through a gas mask—a series hallmark—remains one of the most effective tension-building mechanics in gaming.

The narrative itself is both epic and intimate, balancing the personal story of Artyom’s quest for hope with a broader look at the remnants of civilization. The pacing can vary, with certain sections slowing down to emphasize exploration and emotional beats before ramping up into explosive set pieces. Some players may find these shifts jarring, particularly those expecting the tightly linear structure of previous Metro games, but the variety ultimately enriches the experience. Each chapter feels distinct, offering different gameplay rhythms and emotional tones, from desperate survival in desolate landscapes to moral choices that determine the fate of both individuals and entire communities. The game’s endings reflect these decisions, reinforcing the theme that in a world already destroyed, what matters most is how you choose to live.

Despite its ambition, Metro Exodus is not without flaws. Certain technical issues, such as stiff animations or minor bugs, occasionally break immersion. The stealth mechanics can feel inconsistent depending on environmental design, and the AI behavior sometimes swings between sharp and oblivious. Additionally, while the narrative offers powerful moments, some characters outside the core cast receive limited development, and the moral choice system—while impactful—can feel binary in execution. Yet even with these shortcomings, the game’s atmosphere and craftsmanship overshadow its imperfections. Every chapter, every ruined village or abandoned factory, tells a story through its design, inviting players to piece together fragments of humanity’s past while forging their own path forward.

Metro Exodus succeeds not only as a continuation of a beloved series but as a statement of ambition from 4A Games. It transforms a once claustrophobic survival horror experience into a sprawling yet intimate journey about resilience, faith, and the enduring search for home. The result is a rare kind of shooter—one that values patience and emotion as much as precision and firepower. It’s a haunting, beautiful, and deeply human story set against the desolation of a dying world. For those who embrace its deliberate pacing and attention to detail, Metro Exodus offers an experience that lingers long after the credits roll—a testament to the idea that even in the darkest corners of apocalypse, hope can still find a way to shine through the dust.

Metro Exodus is easily the biggest and best game of the series; all the hard work and development 4A Games built up since 2010 culminates in an expansive and poignant adventure with just a few small stumbles along the way.

Some time after Metro Last Light, Artyom clings to the hope that a better life exists beyond the underground tunnels. By chance, him and his wife Anna discover a fully functioning train and a long-buried truth that has been hidden for decades. A long journey begins as Artyom, Anna, Colonel Miller and the rest of the Order set out to find a new home. The story is certainly the best yet with a genuinely likeable and charismatic group of characters. From a writing standpoint, Anna has been vastly improved from the last entry and there is a greater sense of hope that compels you onward.

But the developer didn't stop there; they drastically expanded the scale and scope of the levels, taking some inspiration from Metal Gear Solid 5 and other open-world titles. The Volga River and Caspian Desert chapters are both brilliant showcases of building landscapes that feel real. There are no tickbox objectives, tedious busywork or pointless collectables. Everything has been hand-crafted from bandit camps to the main missions. It all blends so well with the franchise's deep immersion and completionists will gladly explore every nook and cranny.

The gameplay remains as visceral and engaging as ever with a few important tweaks. The bullet economy is gone, replaced by a handy crafting system. With tons of different weapons, attachments, repairs and upgrades, you have more free rein over your chosen armaments. The stealthy approach is also much more viable with the day/night cycle feeding right into your infiltration. There's a good balance between humans and monsters in combat and the title still packs plenty of tension with Artyom's fragile health pool.

It has some issues here and there, namely some ocassionally clunky movement and a lacklustre boss fight or two, but Metro Exodus is a must-own for all fans of shooters, horror and atmospheric immersion. There's no doubt that 4A are at the top of their game and I'm looking forward to what they put out next. The Two Colonels and Sam's Story DLC packs are also worth getting to expand things further.

Last Light is a little more coherent in some aspects, and I think the larger focus on the Metro as multiple micro-nations is definitely really cool, but it suffers from similar problems.

Exodus' story is... not amazing, if you treat it as 1 large story, but if you treat chapters as individual stories, the perception changes quite a bit. 
The first area, the Volga, is cool, and really hits you with a similar atmosphere, to what S.T.A.L.K.E.R. had. The no-electricity fish cult is neat, but a little shallow. I also think its akward that they're using weaponry made using machinery, aka, electricity. I think it'd be cooler, if they had like, handmade weaponry, such as a handgonne maybe. Firearms that you could have realistically made without power tools.
The Yamantau bunker is such abysmal dogshit narratively, its actually insane. Rarely have I seen someone fuck up that bad. Literally the only redeeming quality of Yamantau is, that it was a fun shooting gallery, that was about it. Other than that, it was just silly, thats all it was. It was cartoonish, and not in a good way. Some of the notes you can pick up especially, just make you feel embarrassed for whoever wrote those. Imagine writing something for a game, and you deadass put "M mmm MMa ma me mme me mmmeeeeat" into a note. You know, because the people of Yamantau are cannibals? You get it?... Yeah, this is genuinely so bad. Yamantau could have been such a cool area, if the developers simply... toned it down... A LOT. I think it would have been really memorable, if the cannibals were calm and collected, maybe even playing along with the idea, that they are the remaining government, until they actually manage to get you to bring the train there, and you end up having to save everybody. Instead, its just the average Black Ops: Zombies map...
The second open world-ish area of the game, the Caspian, is also cool, but genuinely just too long. This is most likely very not true factually, but it feels as if the Caspian part of the game, is like 60% of the entire experience. I am not playing Metro, so that I can walk/drive through a desert, for who knows how long. I think the baron is kind of funny, because he got a similar relationship to us, as Rais from Dying Light had with the protagonist, which is, that its just kinda one sided. Its like that meme with the lion shouting at the monkey, who's just kinda looking at the lion in a smug way. I think they could have done a bit more with the resistance against the baron, because we didn't actually do too much overall, aside from one very obvious point, which I guess wasn't even necessarily our doing.
The third and last open world-ish area of the game, the Taiga, is probably my favorite, genuinely. Not just do I think that the faction there is really interesting, but I am also VERY happy, that out of all 3 open world-ish areas, its the least open one. Metro, as the name suggests, plays, or at least played, inside a Metro system, aka, you could probably not get any more linear, by design, if you tried. So when I started Exodus for the first time, and was met with semi-open worlds, I was immediately put off. I thought the Taiga was a good compromise between open world, and the linearity that the Metro franchise is known for. Aside from the borderline forced non-lethal stealth, which was partly so ass due to my inability to quicksave, due to playing on ranger hardcore, there isn't too much I have to complain about in the Taiga.
The last area of the game, the Dead City, is definitely one where Metro showed once more, at what it truly shines, which is linearity and atmosphere. Going through the Dead City feels almost surreal, which was most likely the intention. I also don't actually have too much of a problem with [spoiler]Miller's death[/spoiler]. Often the issue is, that games will try to forcefully make a [spoiler]characters death sad[/spoiler], which often just ends up making it feel silly. And while the like, epiphany that Artyom has, after returning from the Dead City, where you talk to [spoiler]Miller's ghost, where he actually tells you something new, somehow, aka, clear proof that straight up super natural things exist in the Metro universe, aside from just strange anomalies[/spoiler], is rather silly. I think the actual ending ending is a little too abrupt, personally, I wouldn't have minded if, instead of [spoiler]Miller's ghost somehow telling them where to go[/spoiler], we would have had maybe 10 - 20 minutes more of walking around and watching cutscenes, and listening to dialogue, until Artyom and the gang find a nice place to live by themselves. Maybe with a little cutscene where its like "8 months later", and you can clearly see Anna being pregnant, and then the camera fades to black. That would have been a pretty cool ending, I think.

Overall, I'd give Metro Exodus an 8/10.
